title: Unable to extend virtual dependencies
body:
Two core tenets of Spack are the idea of virtual packages (where multiple implementations of a library provide the same API) and extensions (where a package can be symlinked to a dependency prefix). Unfortunately, these two tenets are currently incompatible, and virtual dependencies cannot be extended.

### Rationale

There are many extendable packages in Spack that either have virtual dependencies or would benefit from having them. For example:

Java has [several implementations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Java_virtual_machines):

- Oracle JDK
- OpenJDK
- IBM Java
- IcedTea

Java is already a virtual package in Spack.

Python has [several implementations](https://www.python.org/download/alternatives/):

- CPython
- Anaconda
- Miniconda
- PyPy
- Jython
- IronPython
- Intel Python

Many users have requested that Python become a virtual dependency (#7966).

### Description

I first noted this behavior in #8613, but for a virtual dependency like `java`, if you write:
```python
extends('java')
```
in a package, concretization will crash with the following error message:
```
==> Error: Package 'java' not found.
```
For now, you have to write `extends('jdk')` if you want it to work. Of course, this prevents users from using `openjdk` or any other Java provider. This problem will become even more apparent once we make Python a virtual dependency.

### Additional information

There are several other issues that are related to this issue that we should also solve:

- Unable to extend multiple packages (#987)
- Virtual dependencies do not support variants (#1712, #6300)
- Extensions do not support variants (#10195)
- Multiple providers found for virtual dependency (#4107, #7339, #7901, #8059, #8133, #9753, #11987, #13821, #20308)
